column4: Econometric Analysis looks at variables/factors that might be causing an effect
column5: Researchers want to be able to infer that one variable (such as race or ethnicity) has a causal effect on another variable (probability of being stopped by the police).
column6: In much scientific research, scientists can set up controlled experiments — having a control and treatment group — in order to isolate cause and effect.
column7: However, for many "real world" research questions, it is often difficult, prohibitively expensive, or morally repugnant to conduct such experiments.
column8: The power of multiple regression analysis is that it allows us to do in non-experimental environments what natural scientists are able to do in a controlled laboratory setting: keep other factors fixed
column9: For the Racial Profiling Prohibition Study, two econometric test were used: KPT Hit Rate and the Veil of Darkness

column4: Two Approaches: KPT Hit Rate & Veil of Darkness
column5:
KPT Hit Rate:
  • Hit Rate = # of times contraband found/# of times cars searched
  • Question: Are the observed rates different than the expected rates?
  • Hypothesis: If racial bias didn't exist, the rate of contraband found relative to the total number of searches across motorist groups would be equal
  • White is the control group and minorities are the treatment
  • The statistical test calculates the probability of a stop resulting in a hit across different racial grroups
column6:
Veil of Darkness:
  • Hypothesis: if police officers are profiling motorists, they would be more likely to do so during daylight hours when race and ethnicity are more easily discernible
  • If racial bias is not present in traffic stops, the probability of minorities and non-minorities being stopped during the day should not be statistically different than stops during the night.
  • Establishes a 'natural experiment' meaning it creates a treatment and control group in an effort to mimic a randomized control setting
